items.title: Add statement list for ignore option
items.body:
Hi and thank you for this very useful module !

Is is possible to use more than one function for ignore option?

Very helpful to handle ignores, such as not have to create a specific function for each question but ignore this or that condition.

`ignore=[function1, function2]`

❤️

items.title: Maintain
items.body: Is this library being maintainable? I would love to use in one of my projects.

items.title: Add quick navigation options
items.body: It would be really nice to be able to quickly jump to a line number or something for List prompts that have many options.

items.title: Inquirer seems to capture control-C inputs on the Confirm prompt
items.body: Is there a different way to exit a script that is in the middle of a Confirm prompt?

items.title: Add Editor prompt type
items.body: Inquirer.js has the [Editor](https://github.com/SBoudrias/Inquirer.js#editor---type-editor) prompt type, which I've just realized I need in my Python project currently using this inquirer port. Would be happy to help add it, if there are contribution docs or just point me in the right direction!

items.title: 2.5.2 publish
items.body: I see that there's a `2.5.2` tag, but I'm unable to install it with `pip3`. On pip3, it says the latest is `2.5.1`. Are there plans to publish `2.5.2` onto pypi?

items.title: Windows support
items.body:
As mentioned in README, currently Windows is not supported because python-inquirer depends on `blessing` package, which does not support Windows at this moment.

There is some hope that this will change in the future: https://github.com/erikrose/blessings/issues/21

This issue is here to track progress on this problem.

items.title: Text question with default that is int ==> crash
items.body:
If I provide an int as default for text question, then when I want to modify the value exception is raised `TypeError: object of type 'int' has no len()`. 

I can understand that it could be the user who should fix this, but in the same time it would improve the usability of this library if these small things would be handled. 

I can provide PR for it.

items.title: Programmatically making selections for testing
items.body:
First off, I just want to say that I think this package does a great job of allowing for more interactive and accessible python CLI's.  
Though I've spent some time attempting to simulating keypresses or programmatically make selections within a unit-test and have been unsuccessful so far. Is there a method for accomplishing this that I'm missing?

items.title: Cannot move cursor for Text based question
items.body:
If I have enter some text value into text-based question and want to correct some typo or something, I can not just move the cursor to the position and do the change. Instead, I have to delete everything before and then do the modification and retype everything.

This is quiet UX bummer... Not sure if it is general behavior or bug at my environment.

items.title: Inquirer License
items.body:
Hi, I noticed License is missing (neither a LICENSE file nor comments with the license in code).

That's kinda a big deal for anyone caring to contribute to this cool repo.

items.title: Confirm question ignores SIGINT
items.body: When Confirm question is active you can not interrupt the process with Ctrl+C (eq. SIGINT signal).

items.title: Handling many choices in List/Checkbox
items.body:
If there is high number of choices in List or Checkboxes the behavior is far from optional. The list will overflow the screen and navigation becomes practically impossible.

I suggest limiting the size of "scrollbox" to a certain number of lines and scroll through the box when person navigate to the end/beginning. 

Also, I would suggest adding filtering/auto-suggesting feature, which would allow the user to start typing while in the List/Checkbox question, which would filter out the choices displayed.

@magmax do you think the proposed solution&feature is feasible? If so, I could work on it, if you would accept the PR...

items.title: Leaking secret through Password validation message
items.body:
Today I realized that when you use Password question and supply invalid value, the entered value is prompted in plaintext in the error message. 

I believe that this should not be the correct behavior as it could resolve in accidental leaking the secret to the surrounding (in a sense, somebody watching over my shoulder).

I would inspire regarding how to approach this from well-established utilities like `sudo`, which does not even print any chars to prevent from leaking the length of the secret.

I could do PR to fix this.

items.title: Ascii Issue
items.body:
This is all a learning experience for me so the answer may be obvious and I am just missing it.

If I create a list as such:
```
LangQuestion = [
    inquirer.List('lang',
                  message="Select Language",
                  choices=['English', 'Français', 'Deutsche'],
              ),# ç
]

answers = inquirer.prompt(LangQuestion)

pprint(answers)
```
It breaks due to UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 4: ordinal not in range(128)

However anywhere else in my project where I reference Français and does not involve using inquirer it works fine. Is there a way to expand the ascii to accommodate such characters? I thought UTF-8 would cover all of it to begin with but again this is outside of my realm of knowledge.

Thank you for your time!

items.title: Validation of group of Questions
items.body:
Hey there,

First of all thanks for great tool!

I am wondering how to do validation of a group of questions. The use-case is pretty simple if I ask for login credentials (typical username & password) in two separate questions I can put validation on the later one and access the value of the first one through `answers`. So far, so good. 
The issue is that if the validation fails, the user can change only the value of the second Question not the first one. 

Is there some way how to rollback to the first Question?

Thanks

items.title: List glitch with too many choices
items.body:
Hi, 

I found that the List glitch refreshing all the items if there are many. It is also depends on the size of terminal window though. 

The following example can show the problem:

```
    choices = []
    for x in range(0, 50):
        choices.append( x )

    questions = [
        inquirer.List('number',
            message="Pick a number:",
            choices=choices
        ),
    ]

    answer = inquirer.prompt(questions)
```

I am on Mac OS X 10.12.6
Python 2.7.14
inquirer 2.2.0

items.title: Fails to install on Python 3.6
items.body:
```
Collecting readchar==0.7 (from inquirer->almar==0.7.2)
  Using cached readchar-0.7.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-build-33aeocmc/readchar/setup.py", line 15, in <module>
        long_description=read_description(),
      File "/tmp/pip-build-33aeocmc/readchar/setup.py", line 9, in read_description
        return fd.read()
      File "/opt/rh/rh-python36/root/usr/lib64/python3.6/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
        return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
    UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc3 in position 2461: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Per https://github.com/magmax/python-readchar/issues/26 , this seems to have been fixed in 0.1.0 (or before?).

Note: The version that follows 0.7 is 0.0.8, then 0.0.9 and 0.1.0. Ref: https://pypi.org/project/readchar/#history

* [Version 0.0.8](https://travis-ci.org/magmax/python-inquirer/builds/340541258) fails with Python 3.3
* [Version 0.0.9](https://travis-ci.org/magmax/python-inquirer/builds/340549525) fails with Python 3.3
* [Version 0.1.0](https://travis-ci.org/magmax/python-inquirer/builds/340521472) fails with Python 2.7

items.title: Choices should allow for a separate list of display names
items.body: The choices list for Checkbox and List questions should allow for either an additional `display` argument, or accept a a list of lists, where the first element of list item is the value to return and the second is what to display in the list of choices

items.title: theme customization
items.body:
Hello there, 
first of all, thanks for this project! I'm using it and it saves me a lot of time.
Besides that, i think a quite important feature is missing: customization.

I'm currently developing a solution to address that, aka choose color/symbols, at runtime.
A simple usage of what I'm developing would be
```
import inquirer

# question definitions 

class MyTheme(inquirer.Theme):
    # redefine properties

inquirer.prompt(questions, theme=MyTheme) 
```

I would happily contribute to this project, but i'm new to opensource and i can't see a 'contribute readme', so I'm posting here, hoping this feature would be welcome.

items.title: Phone number validation doesn't really work correctly
items.body:
A UK phone number is of the format +44 1234 123456 (country area number). I only include the spaces here to illustrate the format.

It won't accept as valid even if you give the country code as 0044. I've also tried it with my Polish phone number and it won't accept that either.

I've just noticed that the regex is in the code sample itself:

```python
questions = [
  inquirer.Text('name', message="What's your name"),
  inquirer.Text('surname', message="What's your surname"),
  inquirer.Text('phone', message="What's your phone number",
                validate=lambda x, _: re.match('\d+', x),
                )
]
```
However, there's no value I seem to be able to give it that will pass validation. I haven't forgotten to import re.

items.title: cursor down on last choice should select first choice
items.body: from my experience using inquirer.js I expected to move back to the first choice once I press cursor down on the last choice of a list. Instead selection stays on the last item.

items.title: multiline message blows up the UI
items.body:
I used a \n in the message of a choices list like I would do in inquirer.js. It displays fine at first but as soon as I move the cursor I prints out extra lines (see screenshot).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/33456/20718876/77fc2914-b65a-11e6-8a03-973a8ae9705b.png)

items.title: inquirer.Separator() missing
items.body:
I could not find the separator. Am I doing sth wrong, or missing feature?
inquirer.js provides two variants:
* inquirer.Separator('some text')
* inquirer.Separator()

items.title: Why catch and swallow KeyboardInterrupt exceptions?
items.body:
Hi,

First, thanks for your work on inquirer, I've used it to replace some custom interactive mode prompts on a cli app and it's a huge improvement on what we had before :-)

On thing that I found odd though, is the way inquirer catches KeyboardInterrupt exceptions, and doesn't re-raise them. This surprised me because I'd expect these exceptions to bubble up to the main/calling application, where they can be handled consistently regardless of where they occur.

Is there a specific reason for catching these exceptions within inquirer itself, or would you be open to accepting a pull request that either removes the code to catch them or at least re-raises them? Personally, I'd vote for the former as I don't think it's the responsibility of a library/package like inquirer to handle these exceptions at all, but then, I'm not really a python programmer, so maybe I'm missing something here.

Thanks

Mark

items.body:
i meet a qusetion that:

```
page_name = inquirer.prompt([
    inquirer.Text('name', message = 'support xxx.html or /xx/xxx.html', 
    validate = lambda x: re.match(r'/?([\w-]+?/)*[\w-]+\.html$', x))
 ])
```

```
page_name = inquirer.prompt([
    inquirer.Text('name', message = 'test', validate = lambda x: True,)
    ])
```

but no matter what i input, it still return      xxx is not a valid name

items.title: add to awesome-python list

Also I would also like to report that sent the pull request to add the library to the awesome-python list, and I hope you don't mind. It's can draw attention to your library, and more contributors who will help you with this lib.

items.title: Ability to override questions defaults
items.body:
Maybe I'm missing something, but I was not able to pass an set of _pre answers_ to the `prompt()` function, to override the default values of the questions.

My use case is double: 
1. I'd like to implement a way to load predefined defaults from a file, before prompting the user
2. An application I wrote ([tinject](https://bitbucket.org/lele/metapensiero.tool.tinject)) has a _cascade_ of prompts, where any question may be repeated: at the second `prompt()` I'd like to be presented the answer given in the first, if any

At first I tried to use the `answers` argument to the `prompt()` function, but it didn't have any effect, and checking the source seems to confirm that.

In lelit@8480308fb09990f5dfe7f2214edf12923e6dd900 I modified the `default` property of the `Question` class to return the answered value, if present. Does that sound reasonable, or is there a better way to accomplish my goal?

items.title: Overwrite Question?
items.body: I would like to use inquirer as a menu. So when I provide a list, and the user selects the answer, I would like inquirer to overwrite the existing question. Is this possible? This feature would be great!

items.body: It would be nice if the choice list is a dictionary so we can have display names and real values (which can be objects).

items.title: python-inquirer does not work on OSX
items.body:
Up and down arrows and enter do not work in List or Checkbox.
Checkbox responds to space bar.
On enter Password simply adds a star.
All other examples seem to work just fine.

items.title: Console display of Text question with default incorrect?
items.body:
I was expecting that a default value for a `Text` question would appear in the text of the question, for instance `"What is your name? (default: Bob)`. This seems to have been an intention, according to `render.console._text.Text.get_message()`, unfortunately that method is never actually called. Instead, you end up with a line like:

```
What is your name? Bob
|
```

Combined with the actual terminal cursor always ending up on the next line (instead of next to the text you're editing), this ends up feeling confusing to me. What are you thoughts?

items.title: Issues with new lines
items.body:
Hi, first of all congratulations and thanks for your work, this is a really nice python module.

I have a couple of small issues:
- the prompts appear in the terminal with an extra new line after each one 
- maybe is related with the previous one: the choices prompt works just right but the next prompt appears on top of the choices list

You can see both issues on this gif:

![inquirer mov](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/159838/5216660/f7b0525e-7636-11e4-9b81-b2d597f6d622.gif)

I do not know if this is important but I tested it using iTerm 2.0 and OSX Terminal, I'm using Yosemite.

Thanks for your help in advance.

items.title: requirements are not installed installed via pip when installing inquirer
items.body:
The readchar and blessings requirements are not installed by pip when attempting to install inquirer.

```
Downloading/unpacking inquirer
  Downloading inquirer-1.0.0.tar.gz
  Running setup.py egg_info for package inquirer
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 16, in <module>
      File "/Users/brendonjohn/Development/numericalbrass/Wool/build/inquirer/setup.py", line 4, in <module>
        from inquirer import __version__
      File "inquirer/__init__.py", line 3, in <module>
        from .prompt import prompt
      File "inquirer/prompt.py", line 3, in <module>
        from .render.console import ConsoleRender
      File "inquirer/render/__init__.py", line 2, in <module>
        from .console import ConsoleRender
      File "inquirer/render/console/__init__.py", line 5, in <module>
        import readchar
    ImportError: No module named readchar
```

The work around is simple: Install the requirements manually.
